label: Catherine Gaultier
description: Catherine Gaultier first worked for Sears for $7 a week, but as a Rosie in Cleveland for Fisher Body she made just over $2 an hour.
content:
Catherine Gaultier first worked for Sears for $7 a week, but as a Rosie in Cleveland for Fisher Body she made just over $2 an hour.  1 
Catherine Gaultier 
 
The Real Rosie the Riveter Project 
Interview 25 
 
 
 
Interview Conducted by  
Kirsten Kelly 
June 26, 2010 
Nashville, Tennessee  
 
 
 
For The 
For the Tamiment Library, Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
New York University 
 
----------------Page (0) Break----------------
 2 
Interview: Catherine Gaultier 
Interviewers: Kirsten Kelly  
Date: June 26, 2010 
Place: Nashville, Tennessee 
 
Gaultier: I’m Catherine Gaultier. 
 
Kelly: And how old? 
 
Gaultier: And I’m 95 years old and then I was one of the- I 
worked. I was a Rosie the Riveter. 
 
Kelly: And how old? 
 
Gaultier: I’m 95 years old. And then I was one of the Rosie 
the Riveter. 
 
Kelly: and where did you work as a Rosie? 
 
Gaultier: I worked in Cleveland, Ohio. I worked for a 
Fisher Body and before that I was working at Sears making 
$7 a week. While I was there three gentlemen came up to me 
and said, “Are you interested in going to be a riveter?” 
And I said, “I don’t know. I’ll have to ask Sears if they 
----------------Page (1) Break----------------
 3 
could release me.” And they went to him and said, 
“certainly you can go.” And that’s how I got my job. 
 
Kelly: And what did you make in Cleveland? 
 
Gaultier: at that time I was making $7 a week at Sears but 
it was little over $2 an hour but I don’t remember exactly 
how much but it wasn’t very much.  But but at that time, it 
was a lot.  
 
Kelly: So when you were a Rosie you made- 
 
Gaultier: Little over $2 an hour. 
 
Kelly: Wow, really? So that was quiet a big difference from 
Sears. 
 
Gaultier: Oh yes, oh yes.  So I was so excited about it and 
I worked there pretty close to three years. And then well I 
was there I had the three children and I had to work at at 
during the day.  Then at night my husband worked. He worked 
to take care of the children. Then he went nights and I had 
the reverse you know. And that’s how I kept staying there. 
And when I was going there at night when I went back to 
----------------Page (2) Break----------------
 4 
work at night, I had to get up real early and get on the 
bus. Make three bus stops at that time because we didn’t 
have the money, we didn’t have the car. And uh so after I 
stayed until the war ended. And while we were there he said 
we’re going outside to stay in the uh the park lot.  They 
were going to have a visitor. So in the meantime, he comes 
an airplane. The b-29 we were all there.  He comes out, he 
tips his wing, went all the way down, came back, tipped it.  
And everybody was- we were crying.  Really crying, it was 
sad. And uh then about three weeks later, I think about 
three weeks, we lost our job because the war ended because 
they went to Iwo Jima. That’s when they bombed that Iwo 
Jima. 
 
03:14:10--------------------------------------------------- 
 
Gaultier: And that was the end of our- my career.  I had to 
go back to sears. 
 
Kelly: What do you think you learned from being a Rosie? 
 
Gauliter: When I went there to be a Rosie, I was so proud 
and so happy and my husband also thought it was just 
wonderful. And so it was just it was just like we were 
----------------Page (3) Break----------------
 5 
playing it was nice.  Everybody was so nice and gentle and 
uh I enjoyed it. I couldn’t wait to go back to work. I 
didn’t want to take care of the children. 
 
Kelly: Do you- Do you have a favorite uh funny memory or a 
funny thing that happened while you were a Rosie? 
 
Gaultier: The only thing- the men always made me do the 
dirty work. I had to get down to the bottom- (laughs). When 
they were bucking I had to be thee to make sure they hit it 
right. And of course, had to be very careful and it had to 
be even you know. It was so- they were something else.  
They were on top and you’d do the bottom. But we had a good 
time. Everybody was so congenial. It was nice. 
 
04:35:21-------------------------------------------------- 
 
Kelly:  What was the feeling like about the war at that 
time? 
 
Gaultier: I was very upset about it you know. I didn’t know 
how long it was going to last you know. And everybody there 
talked so much about death. And it was bad. It was- I knew 
a lot of friends who were going into the service to the w- 
----------------Page (4) Break----------------
 6 
and I really felt bad. But it but it managed. We had to 
keep on going. So but it- everybody was worried about it. 
So when they bombed that and within one week it was all 
gone.  No war. The war ended and I lost my job. 
 
Kelly: Do you remember how you found out you lost your job? 
Do you remember? 
 
Gaultier: Oh yea I remember when I lost the job. 
 
Kelly: What happened? How did you find out that you 
couldn’t- 
 
Gaultier: Oh we were dismissed.  They told us that we were 
all through. Everybody lost their job at that time. And 
then it was- even then I went back to Sears. So- for $7 a 
week. 
 
Kelly: You worked for three years you said? As a Rosie? 
 
Gaultier: Yes. 
 
Kelly: What did you do with the extra money that you were 
making? Do you remember?  
----------------Page (5) Break----------------
 7 
 
Gaultier:  Well we paid of our home. Yes. So we were so 
happy about that. You know, it was nice. 
 
Kelly: Get a jump start? 
 
Gaultier: Oh yes. It was sad it had to be that way but it 
did help us. So- 
 
Kelly: And what did your husband do during the war? 
 
Gaultier: He was- he worked for the railroad.  He worked 
there for 43 years, same one. And that of course he didn’t 
have to go to the service because it was a railroader that 
was important for them to move their materials around you 
know. So that’s why he was there. And he took care of the 
children. 
 
Kelly: A pretty modern husband at that time? 
 
Gaultier: Oh yes yes so and uh, it was nice. I enjoyed 
every minute of it. 
 
The End. 
----------------Page (6) Break----------------
